lesson.name: Lesson 7.5: Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations, Part 1

page.title: 7.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will construct quadratic functions to represent various situations, investigate the movement of free-falling objects, analyze the vertical distances that falling objects travel over time, and see that they can be described by quadratic functions.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain the meaning of the terms in a quadratic expression that represents the height of a falling object.
  • Use tables, graphs, and equations to represent the height of a falling object.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.5.1: Numerical Patterns
  • 7.5.2: A Time-Distance Quadratic Model
    • 7.5.2: Self Check
    • 7.5.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.5.3: Distance as a Quadratic Function of Elapsed Time
    • 7.5.3: Self Check
    • 7.5.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.5.4: A Quadratic Expression that Represents the Relationship Between Distance and Time

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.5.5: Practice
  • 7.5.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.5.1: Numerical Patterns
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity


Study the table. What do you notice? What do you wonder?

\(x\)

0

1

2

3

4

5

\(y\)

0

16

64

144

256

400

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Things you may notice:

  • The \(x\)-values increment by 1 as you move across the table.
  • The \(y\)-values increase.
  • All \(y\)-values are even and divisible by 4, 8, and 16.
  • The \(y\)-values are all perfect squares.
  • The successive differences between the \(y\)-values are growing.

Things you may wonder:

  • Is there a rule for these numbers?
  • Do the numbers represent the growth of a geometric pattern?
  • Do the numbers represent a quadratic relationship?
  • What is the next number in the table?

page.title: 7.5.2: A Time-Distance Quadratic Model
page.contents:
Activity

A rock is dropped from the top floor of a 500-foot-tall building. A camera captures the distance the rock traveled, in feet, after each second.


  1. How many feet will the rock have fallen after 6 seconds? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The rock will have fallen 500 feet after 6 seconds. The distance fallen increased with each additional second. The rock fell 144 feet between 4 and 5 seconds, so between 5 and 6 seconds, it would fall more than 144 feet. After 5 seconds of falling, there is less than 144 feet to go before the rock hits the ground.


  1. Jada noticed that the distances fallen are all multiples of 16.

    She wrote down:

    \(16=16 \cdot 1\)
    \(64=16 \cdot 4\)
    \(144=16 \cdot 9\)
    \(256=16 \cdot 16\)
    \(400=16 \cdot 25\)

Then, she noticed that 1, 4, 9, 16, and 25 are \(1^2\), \(2^2\), \(3^2\), \(4^2\), \(5^2\).


    1. Use Jada’s observations to predict the distance fallen in feet after 7 seconds. (Assume the building is tall enough that an object dropped from the top of it will continue falling for at least 7 seconds.) Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

784



    1. Write an equation for the function, with \(d\) representing the distance dropped after \(t\) seconds.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(d=16 \cdot t^2\)

page.title: 7.5.2: Self Check
page.contents: An object is dropped from a building and falls so that the distance in feet it falls, \(d(t)\), is found by \(d(t)=16t^2\), after \(t\) seconds. How many feet has it fallen after 10 seconds?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to square the time. The answer is 1,600.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to square the 10, not multiply by 2. The answer is 1,600.
That’s correct! Check yourself: When \(t=10\), square the 10 to get 100, then multiply by 16.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Use order of operations and square 10 first. Then multiply by 16. The answer is 1,600.

page.title: 7.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Distance Fallen

The Empire State Building is 1250 ft high (excluding the lightning rod). A visitor drops a penny from the top, and it falls straight down. How far has it fallen after 5 seconds?

Recall the previous activity’s formula \(h(t)=16t^2\).

Substitute \(t=5\).

\(h(5)=16(5)^2=16 \cdot 25=400\) feet.

Try It: Finding Distance Fallen


Will the penny dropped from the Empire State Building reach the ground after 9 seconds? Explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine if the penny will hit the ground by 9 seconds:

Substitute \(t=9\) into \(h(t)=16t^2\).

\(h(9)=16(9)^2=16 \cdot 81=1,296\)

After 9 seconds, the penny could travel 1296 feet. The Empire State Building is 1250 feet tall, so the penny will have hit the ground by 9 seconds.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.5.3: Distance as a Quadratic Function of Elapsed Time
page.contents:
Activity

Galileo Galilei, an Italian scientist, and other medieval scholars studied the motion of free-falling objects. The law they discovered can be expressed by the equation \(d=16t^2\), which gives the distance fallen in feet as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds.

An object is dropped from a height of 576 feet.

  1. How many feet does it fall in 0.5 seconds?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! It falls 4 feet in 0.5 seconds because \(16 (0.5)^2=4\).

The correct answer is 4. It falls 4 feet in 0.5 seconds because \(16 (0.5)^2=4\).

  1. To find out where the object is the first few seconds after it was dropped, Elena and Diego created different tables.

Elena’s table:

Time (seconds)

Distance fallen (feet)

0

0

1

16

2

64

3

4

\(t\)

Diego’s table:

Time (seconds)

Distance from the ground (feet)

0

576

1

560

2

512

3

4

t


    1. How are the two tables alike?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They both have time in seconds and distance in feet as the two quantities being measured. They both show 0–4 seconds and \(t\) seconds for time. They describe the same object falling.



    1. How are the two tables different?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Elena’s table measures distance fallen, and Diego’s table measures distance from the ground. They record measurements from opposite ends. Elena’s table starts with 0 feet for 0 seconds, and Diego’s starts with 576 feet for 0 seconds.


  1. Complete Elena’s table. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.
    1. What is the distance the object has fallen 3 seconds after it was dropped?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 144. The object has fallen 144 feet 3 seconds after it was dropped.

The correct answer is 144. The object has fallen 144 feet 3 seconds after it was dropped.

    1. What is the distance the object has fallen 4 seconds after it was dropped?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 256. The object has fallen 256 feet 4 seconds after it was dropped.

The correct answer is 256. The object has fallen 256 feet 4 seconds after it was dropped.


    1. What is the distance the object has fallen \(t\) seconds after it was dropped?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(16t^2\)


  1. Complete Diego’s table. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.
    1. What is the object’s distance from the ground 3 seconds after it was dropped?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 432. The object is 432 feet from the ground 3 seconds after it was dropped.

The correct answer is 432. The object is 432 feet from the ground 3 seconds after it was dropped.

    1. What is the object’s distance from the ground 4 seconds after it was dropped?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 320. The object is 320 feet from the ground 4 seconds after it was dropped.

The correct answer is 320. The object is 320 feet from the ground 4 seconds after it was dropped.


    1. What is the object’s distance from the ground \(t\) seconds after it was dropped?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

\(576-16t^2\)



Video: Distance as a Quadratic Function of Elapsed Time

Watch the following video to learn more about quadratic functions.

page.title: 7.5.3: Self Check
page.contents: A small ball is dropped from a 350-foot-tall building. Which equation could represent the ball’s height, \(h(t)\), in feet, relative to the ground, as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(t\) is squared in the formula. The answer is \(h(t)=350-16t^2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The ball will fall from 350 feet, so subtract 16 times the time squared to find the height at a given time.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to subtract, not add. The answer is \(h(t)=350-16t^2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Subtract the \(16t^2\) to find the height. The answer is \(h(t)=350-16t^2\).

page.title: 7.5.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Height as a Quadratic Function

The general formula for a free falling object is:

\(h(t)=-16t^2+v_0t+h_0\).

Let’s look at the meaning of the coefficients in the formula:

In the formula, \(-16\) is the constant that has been determined by a combination of Newton’s Laws and Earth’s weight and is used with the units feet/second\(^2\).

\(v_0\) is the vertical speed of the object. If the object is simply dropped, the vertical speed is 0. If the object were thrown upward, this value would be positive, and if the object were thrown down, this value would be negative.

\(h_0\) is the initial height of the object.

A man drops his keys from a restaurant at the top of a 196-foot-tall building. If the keys are free falling, will they reach the ground within 3 seconds?

Step 1
Write an equation for the height at a given time, \(t\).
\(h(t)=196-16t^2\)

Step 2
Substitute \(t=3\) into the function.
\(h(3)=196-16(3)^2\)

Step 3
Solve.
\(h(3)=196-144=52\)

At \(t=3\) seconds, the keys will still have 52 feet to travel to hit the ground.

Try It: Height as a Quadratic Function


Will the keys in the situation above reach the ground after 5 seconds?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine if the keys reach the ground after 5 seconds:

Step 1
Write an equation for the height at a given time, \(t\).
\(h(t)=196-16t^2\)

Step 2
Substitute \(t=5\) into the function.
\(h(5)=196-16(5)^2\)

Step 3
Solve.
\(h(5)=196-400=-204\)

The keys reach the ground before \(t=5\) seconds since substituting in 5 creates a negative height, which implies they have fallen below ground level and does not make sense for this scenario.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.5.4: A Quadratic Expression that Represents the Relationship Between Distance and Time
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The expression \(16t^2\) represents the distance in feet an object falls after \(t\) seconds. Assume an object is dropped from a height of 906 feet.


  1. What is the height of the object in feet 2 seconds after it is dropped?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The object is at 842 feet 2 seconds after it’s dropped. \(906-16(2)^2=906-16(4)=906-64=842\)



  1. Write an expression representing the height of the object in feet \(t\) seconds after it is dropped.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(906-16t^2\)

page.title: 7.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. A rocket is launched in the air and its height, in feet, is modeled by the function \(h\).

Here is a graph representing \(h\).

Select three true statements about the situation.

Correct! The rocket is launched from a height less than 20 feet above the ground. The rocket reaches its maximum height after about 3 seconds. The maximum height of the rocket is about 160 feet.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The rocket is launched from a height less than 20 feet above the ground. The rocket reaches its maximum height after about 3 seconds. The maximum height of the rocket is about 160 feet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A baseball travels \(d\) meters \(t\) seconds after being dropped from the top of a building. The distance traveled by the baseball can be modeled by the equation \(d=5t^2\).

Use this table to answer questions a–g. 

\(t\) (seconds)

\(d\) (meters)

0

  

0.5

  

1

  

1.5

  

2

  

    1. How many meters \((d)\) did the baseball travel in 0 seconds \((t)\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0. The baseball traveled 0 meters \((d)\) in 0 seconds \((t)\) because it has not been dropped yet.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: 0. The baseball traveled 0 meters \((d)\) in 0 seconds \((t)\) because it has not been dropped yet. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many meters \((d\)) did the baseball travel in 0.5 seconds (\(t\))?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1.25. The baseball traveled 1.25 meters (\(d\)) in 0.5 seconds (\(t\)).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: 1.25. The baseball traveled 1.25 meters (\(d\)) in 0.5 seconds (\(t\)). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many meters (\(d\)) did the baseball travel in 1 second (\(t\))?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 5. The baseball traveled 5 meters \((d)\) in 1 second \((t)\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: 5. The baseball traveled 5 meters \((d\\) in 1 second \((t)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many meters (\(d\)) did the baseball travel in 1.5 seconds (\(t\))?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 11.25. The baseball traveled 11.25 meters \((d)\) in 1.5 seconds \((t)\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: 11.25. The baseball traveled 11.25 meters \((d\)\) in 1.5 seconds \((t)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many meters (\(d\)) did the baseball travel in 2 seconds (\(t\))?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 20. The baseball traveled 20 meters (\(d\)) in 2 seconds (\(t\)).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: 20. The baseball traveled 20 meters (\(d\)) in 2 seconds (\(t\)). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Is this graph an accurate representation of the data in the table? 



Correct! Yes. The coordinates plotted on the graph match the data in the table: \((0,0)\), \((0.5,1.25)\), \((1,5)\), \((1.5,11.25)\), \((2,20)\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Yes. The coordinates plotted on the graph match the data in the table: \((0,0)\), \((0.5,1.25)\), \((1,5)\), \((1.5,11.25)\), \((2,20)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Is the baseball traveling at a constant speed?

Correct! The distance traveled is not changing at a constant speed; it is increasing over time. For example, in the first half second, it travels 1.25 meters, and in the next half second, it travels 3.75 meters.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.5.2 and 7.5.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: No. The distance traveled is not changing at a constant speed; it is increasing over time. For example, in the first half second, it travels 1.25 meters, and in the next half second, it travels 3.75 meters. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A small ball is dropped from a 100-foot-tall building. Which equation could represent the ball’s height, \(h(t)\), in feet, relative to the ground, as a function of time, \(t\), in seconds?

Correct! \(h(t)=100-16t^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.5.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(h(t)=100-16t^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.5.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the meaning of the terms in a quadratic expression that represents the height of a falling object.
  • Use tables, graphs, and equations to represent the height of a falling object.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.5.1: Numerical Patterns
    • In this activity, you spent time examining a given table and discovered predictable patterns of the values. The big thing you learned is that the discovered patterns help determine the function rule.
  • 7.5.2: A Time-Distance Quadratic Model
    • In this activity, you built a very simple quadratic model using given time-distance data of a free-falling rock. The big thing you learned is that the motion of a falling object is commonly modeled with a quadratic function.
    • 7.5.2: Self Check
    • 7.5.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.5.3: Distance as a Quadratic Function of Elapsed Time
    • In this activity, you continued to explore how quadratic functions can model the movement of a falling object by evaluating the function seen earlier in the lesson. Then you built a new function to represent the distance from the ground of a falling object \(t\) seconds after it is dropped.
    • 7.5.3: Self Check
    • 7.5.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.5.4: A Quadratic Expression that Represents the Relationship Between Distance and Time
    • In this activity, you wrote expressions that represent the distance in feet of an object when it falls after \(t\) seconds.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.5.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
